Team match. This game took over 10 weeks to conclude but it's only 35 moves long. We were just taking our time I guess. Back then I was rated 1504 (I had completed only 26 games on GameKnot at that time) and my opponent was rated 1490. Our first game ended on 2/24/09 and is annotated titled Aggressive Plans on that date. It's a short little gem that ends on move 26 after white walks black's king over to whites side of the board for a checkmate. White begins this game with the queen's pawn and I reply Indian.
King's Indian Defense.
4. Bg5 is the Smyslov Variation but white pulled up short. His bishop on c4 hinders the "Four Pawn Attack" the popular white treatment of the King's Indian. Black castles.
I guess white will make do with the "Three Pawns Attack".
The pin. Everyone's doing it. I just wanted to fit in.
Time to break up white's center.
Developing with tempo.
Threatening the fork on c2.
Seizing the half-open file with a threat on the undefended pawn at c4.

I was thinking of 15. ... Nxf3+ followed by 16. ... Bxc3 to win a piece but white would ruin it with 16. Qxf3 defending his lonely knight. And then 16. ... Qa5 is refuted by 17. Rfc1 and the knight will escape. Then I realized I could reverse the move order a bit lead with the queen and good things might happen.
A discovered attack against white's rook on a1 given with check.

White is attacking the black pawn at e7 which is a fork of black's king and the rook at c8. That's the only thing that saves his rook on a1 from the discovered attack. However all is not lost this fork was anticipated and is now prevented. And though white's rook will escape white will not remain unharmed.
The white pawn on a2 was free for the taking but it still is. Black senses a two-for-one sale: take one pawn get another free.
Sold!
Let's see if this passed pawn can make something of himself.
Black really wants his queen on c3 but there is a little problem of white's knight. Time to chase it away.
Oops. 28. Nf6+? looked like a fork but it was well defended. Black didn't expect to chase the knight there. White loses a piece.

Now we're on c3. 31. Qxc3 is just about forced at this point a trade that greatly favors black given his material lead and passed pawn. Said pawn is dangling undefended and en prise tempting white to remove his queen from vital defense.

31. ... Qh3!! needs a pair of exclamations. Well maybe only 1. It's one of the scariest moves I've played in a long time. Black is leaving his rook en prise and white can capture it with check gaining a tempo. That's usually certain doom but oddly enough in this case even that extra tempo won't let the white queen return to defense in time as she has to run around the forest of black pawns. There is always the fear of perpetual check and 3-move repetitions but nothing of that sort presents itself to white either so it's time for the poor rook to take one for the team.

White took the bait and now he's doomed. I suspect he may have realized it too for he didn't return to this game for almost the full three days. I took the time to enter the final Conditional moves in all their possible combinations including queen stalling moves with Qh8+ Qg8+ Qf8+ and Qxf7+ (which came up in several combinations adding 4 extra conditional variations to each combination) and ended up with something like 25 or 30 combinations. The immediate threat of course is 33. ... Qh7#
33. f4 blocked the immediate mate. White's next move is forced.
White could have held out for another two moves with 35. Kh1 Qxf2 36. Qxf7+ Kxf7 37. (any) Qg1# - not that it really mattered.

Oops again. 14. ... Qb4?? was truly a decisive blunder. Already down a piece and a pawn white cannot afford the outright loss of his queen and resigns on the spot. A bit anticlimactic after my near-death experience against the same opponent in our last game (refer to the Giving Him a Little Rope #2 annotation).

I'm not sure what the benefit of voluntarily cornering the king at h1 accomplished. Sure the a7-g1 diagonal is open but white has a bishop safely on it at e3 and the king could always move after a check since there are no forks or other dangers. It seemed premature for white to play 13. Kh1.
Forking the undefended bishop on e3 and the undefended pawn on b2 forcing white's reply.
Seizing the half-open file.
Voluntarily isolating my own pawn on c4 seems questionable now in hindsight.
Since he's isolated lets see about trading him off maybe with the gain of a pawn in the process.

And now black's queen forks two undefended pawns. One must die. White could try 22. Nb3 blocking black's queen from taking the pawn at a3 but the a3 pawn is doubly attacked and black can simply reply 22. ... Bxa3 or even better 22. ... Bxb3 23. cxb3 Rxb3 24. Rxb3 Qxb3 and now black still has two attackers on the a3 pawn and will win two pawns instead of one. White chose to resign at this point. I asked him why since being just one pawn down in an otherwise equal middlegame is usually not cause for resignation and he replied that he didn't think he could hold either pawn and would end up two pawns down facing a black passed pawn and with all black pieces attacking. In any case it was short and sweet.

Hi everyone here I get into a reasonable position in the endgame and with a draw in sight guess what - I go and blow it again.  It has to be said that a skillful bit of camouflage on Freddy's part was a contributory factor in my blundering in this game.  I kick off with e4.
2. ........ d6 - the Philidor's Defence Freddy decides to back up his e pawn with a pawn.  Freddy plays into a line where an early queen trade ensues.
4. dxe5 - the start of the trade.
6........ Kxd8 - the queens have been traded - Looking at this position it seems hard to believe that I end up getting Freddied yet again!
8. Be3 - development.
10. 0-0-0 - as it looks as though we are nearing an endgame I feel queenside castling instead of kingside castling is better.
12. exf5 - I decide to take on f5 in order to give Freddy an isolani.
14. Bd3 - challenging the b1-h7 diagonal.  This precipitates an exchange of light square bishops.
16. Bg5 - I decide to pin Freddy's knight to his rook.
17. ......  Rxd8 - now 1 pair of rooks is exchanged.
18. ..... Be7 - Freddy breaks the pin.
20. Kxd1 - the remaining rooks are exchanged and now it is an endgame - after just 20 moves.
22. Bh4 - keeping the f6 pawn pinned to Freddy's dsb.  I bring Henry out to e2 next move.
24. g4 - to hold back f5.
27. Be1 - to stop the possibility of a bishop sac on b4.

28. Ke3?? - here is the error.  Do you see the camouflage?  Freddy reveals all in the next two moves and my position unravels big time.  Freddy had this to say about what I should have played here:-  "I tell you what I would have moved if I were on your side of the board.. 28. Ke2 instead of Ke3 > this to avoid a possible check from the bishop 29. h4 instead of gxf5 > avoid double pawns and keep your pawn line connected"
31. Kd1 - Freddy had this to say about my king move:- "What about 31. Bd2 and try to exchange or lock in my bishop..."
33. Kb1? - and Freddy had this to say about my move to b1. "I would have moved 33. f6 or Bh4"
35. fxe4+? - would f5 have been an improvement?
38. Kc2 - the only way to hold on to the c pawn.  Freddy surprises me with b4.
41. ..... a2+ and # in 4.  Notice that this is a decoy.  Henry must capture but the c pawn now crowns.
44. ...... Qb2 CHECKMATE.  A sad end.

And there it is black's big blunder. 34. ... f6? was a mistake that guarantees a draw. I think white might have made the wrong decision. Taking the pawn at h7 gives white a passed pawn. Maybe he can find a way to promote maybe not but after capturing at h7 black will be playing for a draw. But by capturing at e6 now black is the one who will get a passed pawn and it will be white playing for a draw. Either way both lines would likely be draws but it seems better to put your opponent on the defensive rather than the other way around. Black forces the queen exchange and gains his passed pawn.
This game is a dead draw unless one of the players has no idea how to play engames.

I could have offered a draw here or either of the previous two moves but I wanted my opponent to show me he could handle himself in an endgame first. Obviously white wants to get in front of the black pawn on e4 and if he does so then we have a draw. But if he backs off to h2 an obvious mistake then black wins. So I give white the rope to see if he'll hang himself.

All by the book. 5. ... a6 is the Najdorf Variation the most popular line in the Sicilian. The move prepares 6. ... e5. If black plays 5. ... e5 then white replies 6. Bb5+ which causes weaknesses in black's position. Hence 5. ... a6 prevents that as well as keeping the two white knights away from b5.
6. Be2 is a little timid much quieter than 6. Be3 or 6. Bg5. Black just follows the main premise of the Najdorf playing 6. ... e5 without fear of the 7. Bb5 reprisal.
By the book.
White commits to some fireworks in the center and now both sides have an isolated center pawn.
White threatened a discovered attack by his bishop at e3 against the black queen at b6.

I played this move nearly a month ago and right now I am not sure why. It puts two attackers on the white pawn at a2 but he has two defenders and can easily be pushed forward to a3. From a5 the black queen can quickly reach the kingside. She covers e5 but she did that from c7 as well. It opens the half-open c-file for a rook but there is little for that rook to do. I think the main thing that motivated this move was fear of white playing Nd5 which would fork the black queen on c7 and black knight on f6 and almost force black to reply with Nxd5 allowing white to play exd5 freeing him from an isolated pawn. White only needs one more piece to make it work such as with Qf3.
To move to the queenside.

Threatening the white bishop on d4 and pinning it to the white king. Black's pawn at d6 is undefended but black will lose material if he takes it. 19. Qxd6? is met with 19. ... Rc6! and now black's queen has nowhere to run that still defends the white bishop on d4. Not 20. Qe5?? because that bishop on d4 is pinned so it cannot recapture after black plays 20. ... Qxe5. And counterattacking with 20. Bxb6?? fails to 20. ... Qxb6+ giving check which gives time for 21. ... Rxd6 and white loses his queen.
White was threatening 20. Bxf6 gxf6 21. Qxf6 gaining a pawn and a strong kingside attack. The bishop exchange puts an end to this threat.
Forking rook and bishop.

The black knight at e5 is pinned; if it moves then white plays Qxg7#. The pawn at g2 is only defended by the black king. If white gets a second attacker on g7 bad things will happen. 22. ... Kh8 opens the space at g8 for a rook to assist with the defense of g7. Meanwhile the isolated pawn on d6 is still undefended and en prise.

This move 23. Qxd6? gets a ? for removing a defender of the knight at f3 which lets black win material. Now the black queen wants to fork then fork again but white's queen is in the way. I think during the game I had a plan to handle 24. Qb4 but now looking at it I have no idea what that plan was and this looks like white's saving move here. Maybe I'll re-analyze it later but right now I think I'm glad white didn't find this move.
There we go. Fork number 1 king and pawn.
Fork number 2 the winning fork. The rook on a1 and knight on c3 are both en prise and white can only save one of them.
27. Qg5 threatens mate in 1 with Qxg7#. Black needs to defend so why not defend with an attack that wins more material?
Black has gained a pawn and now threatens to exchange more material.
Now white's in trouble. The king cannot run to the corner or black plays 31. ... Qxe1. So 31. Kf2 is forced and it begins a little sightseeing vacation for the white king.

Black is looking for angles to trade queens. This would leave him with a bishop+pawn material advantage and white's pawn structure in total disarray.  If white blocks with his queen 32. Qe3 Qxe3 and black trades queens and gains an easy endgame. If white blocks with his rook 32. Re3 Qd2+ 33. Kf3 Be2+ 34. Kf4 Rc3 wins the white rook.

32. Rc6! seals black's doom. The threat is that black can move the rook around the 6th rank checking the white king and eventually pinning the queen to the king and winning white's queen. Black doesn't have any way out. If he runs with 33. Qc1 then 33. ... Rf6+ 34. Kg4 Be6+ 35. Kh4 Rh6+ wins white's queen by forcing 36. Qxh6 (36. Kg5 Qe5#). White could try to make a bolt-hole with 33. g4  but 33. ... Rf6+ 34. Kg3 Qe5+ 35. Kh4 Rh6+ wins white's queen for a rook. Black entered the conditional moves from this point until the capture of the white queen or to checkmate depending on white's choices.
White tried to offer the queen exchange but black isn't interested. Why trade queen for queen when you can trade rook for queen instead?
And now white must play 36. Qxh6 to avoid mate.
Final position.

White opts for the Maroczy Bind
opens c8-h3 diagonal bishop and knight are now attacking g4.
Covers g4.  Now is Black's last chance to play Nxd4 and force White to recapture with queen as White can play Be3 without the Black knight coming to g4.
Black takes the d4 knight while White has to recapture with the Queen "The Gurgenidze System".
The two main choices are 9 Bg5 and 9 Be3.  Both choices could lead to same position that is reached in the game.
11 O-O is the alturnative.

The proper time to offer the Queen exchange. The move ...a6 left a hole at b6 the knight threatens to fork the black rooks after the queens are exchanged so Black will have to spend a tempo to protect against the fork.
to protect against the threatened fork.

The exchange allows White to start a kingside attack.  When the Queens were on the board Black would counter a kingside demonstration with ...b5 which would be very dangerous for White with his king in the center of the board.  Now ...b5 is relatively harmless.
Note that this same position could have been reached with 9 Be3 in one move less since Black would not have played 16...f6 but gone straight to16...f5.
One of Black's main ideas in this line is to try and power through the break ...d5 to show that the White king does not belong in the center.
Here I break with the data bases for the first time.  21 g5 has been played here to prevent ...Nf6.
guess the knight wasn't going to f6 anyway.  Possibly better for Black would be 21...d5 22 cxd5 Nf6 when White would have a slight edge at best.
I think White is definitely better at this point.

I decide to go into an endgame.  After the exchanges on c6 and c5 there are several factors that induced me to go into the endgame; but White could have maintained his advantage with 25 Nd5! For example:  ...Rd7 26 Nb6  Rc7 27 Bd5+ Kh8 28 Rhd1 Ne4 29 Bxe4 Bxe4 30 c5!
White may still have an edge with a better pawn structure and centralized king but I think the position is close to equal.
White aims for what he hopes to be a good knight vs. bad bishop endgame.

This is the position I was playing for.  White has the better pawn structure on the queenside where the Black bishop can't touch his pawns.  An important factor is that the Black bishop is the wrong color for his h-pawn and cannot control the queening square.  If some type of mutual zugzwang position is reached on the kingside White has two pawn moves a2-a3 & a3-a4 on the queenside.  White has the better king position.   However with pawns on both sides of the board the long reaching bishop is probably the better minor piece.
If Black keeps his bishop on the h2-g8 diagonal it is hard to see how White can make progress.

At this point I was starting to consider ways to get a draw.  The White King has to stay at f3 to keep the Black king from invading at g4 and if the knight leaves g2 the White kingside pawns fall.  If Black moved his bishop somewhere on the h2-b8 diagonal I was going to play Ne3 and take the f5 pawn while Black gobbled up my g&h pawn.  It looked like I could win the c6 pawn with my knight.  After that I could play a2-a3 b3-b4 and trade off my knight and queenside pawns for Black's queenside pawns.  The h-pawn dark-square bishop and king vs lone White king was a book draw.

?? Black trades into a lost pawn endgame.  35 ...f4 is interesting.  White is in zugzwang on the kingside and has to use one of his pawn tempi on the queenside.  After that Black must shuttle his bishop between g3 & h2 while White shuttles his knight from g2 to e1.

Hi everyone!  I have recently been annotating games based on chess blunders and some of the types of blunder we all encounter in our chess careers.  But why do we blunder?  Do they come from a clear blue sky e.g. as a result of lack of concentration or poor board analysis?  Or does our opponent put us under so much pressure that we succumb and make that irreversible blunder?  In this game Freddy does put the squeeze on. Hi all here is a little gamelet from about when I first started chess - maybe a month later. A little informal blitz tournament which came after a coaching session. I had the misfortune of being paired against a good friend of mine in Round 2...for his sakes I'll call him N.N. (I'd just like to make it clear that this game is for entertainment value only as with many blitz games!). Anyway onto the moves...you can see how old this game is as I was at the time playing 1.e4.
The uncommon Nimzowitsch Defence. Develops a piece.

Premature. The best move is definitely 2.d4 here occupying the centre. At the time I was hoping to mess up Black's pawn formation by doubling his pawns on the c-file. As a beginner I for some reason saw doubled pawns as an out-and-out liability...a weakness which resulted in many a painful loss.

Forcing Black to waste a tempo with his knight had not occurred to me for the simple reason that at the time I had no comprehension whatsoever of the value of time (i.e. number of moves) in chess. However my favourite activity was using the underestimated pawns to shove my opponents' pieces around. Knights are particularly susceptible to this as we are about to see.
Yay! Gaining space with tempo and my opponent's silly horse has to leap out of sight.
Not quite out of sight. Never mind. I had no intention of relenting from annoying and harrassing my opponent's pieces.
The intrepid pawns move forward into the opponent's half and the stupid knight has to get some more exercise.
The knight is running around in circles. Truly pawns are the soul of chess (Andre Dani Philidor).
